conclusion: The problem involves an ideal gas undergoing changes in pressure and volume as shown in the figure, with segment BC being a hyperbola indicating \( pV = \text{constant} \).
The equation of state for an ideal gas is \( pV = nRT \), where \( n \) and \( R \) are constants.
Given values: \( T_A = 300 \, \text{K} \), \( p_A = 4 \, \text{atm} \), \( V_A = 10 \, \text{L} \), \( p_D = 2 \, \text{atm} \), \( V_D = 20 \, \text{L} \). The goal is to find \( T_D \).
Using state A, \( p_A V_A = nRT_A \), substitute \( p_A = 4 \, \text{atm} \), \( V_A = 10 \, \text{L} \), and \( T_A = 300 \, \text{K} \) to calculate \( nR \).

Using \( pV = \text{constant} \) for states B and C, and given \( p_B V_B = p_C V_C \), substitute \( p_C = 2 \, \text{atm} \), \( V_C = 40 \, \text{L} \), and \( p_B = 4 \, \text{atm} \) to find \( V_B \).

Using the equation of state \( pV = nRT \) for state D, substitute \( nR = \frac{2}{15} \, \text{atm} \cdot \text{L/K} \), \( p_D = 2 \, \text{atm} \), and \( V_D = 20 \, \text{L} \) to calculate \( T_D \).
The temperature of the gas in state D is \( 300 \, \text{K} \).
